p: Recently, El Mamy et al. ( 2014) have reported confirmatory evidence for a field camel infection with RVF. In September of 2010, an RVF outbreak occurred in northern Mauritania involving mass abortions in small ruminants and camels ( Camelus dromedarius) and at least 63 human clinical cases, including 13 deaths. In camels, serological prevalence was 27.5â€“38.5 %, and for the first time, clinical signs other than abortions were reported in this species, including hemorrhagic septicemia and severe respiratory distress (Fig. 20.4). Phylogenetic analyses of the genome of isolates from camels suggested a shared ancestor between the Mauritania 2010 strain and strains from Zimbabwe, Kenya, South Africa, Uganda, and other strains linked to the 1987 outbreak of RVF in Mauritania.
